column2: Martin is the Western Mail's political editor-at-large. He joined Wales on Sunday in 1994, moving on to the Western Mail eight years later, where he served as chief reporter until taking up his current role in 2020. He specialises in controversial and investigative stories and has been involved in covering the National Assembly since its outset. His book on the Assembly's first decade, Poor Man's Parliament, was published in 2011.
Jack is WalesOnline's commercial editor. He started in 2015 as a commercial writer and now oversees all sponsored content.
Ciaran Jones is deputy head of news and former investigations editor at WalesOnline
Mark Smith is the health correspondent for Media Wales.

Nick is former head of content and now a part-time multi-media page editor for Media Wales. He began his journalistic career as a trainee reporter in Skegness in 1989 and joined the South Wales Echo as a senior reporter in August, 1998. He enjoys films, cooking and following Lincoln City.
Peter was chief reporter of the South Wales Echo from 2010 to 2013, having relocated from Perth, Australia. Peter returned to Western Australia in 2013, joining The Sunday Times newspaper.
Photographer and picture editor at Media Wales
Laura McAllister is a sports-mad academic from Bridgend. She is Professor at Cardiff University’s Wales Governance Centre and former captain of the Wales women’s international football team.
Ceredigion boy working on the Newsdesk at WalesOnline after many years as a reporter in newsrooms across South West Wales. Armchair sports aficinado with an unhealthy love for Gareth Bale

Kathryn is our online showbiz news reporter. Rhondda-born Kathryn handles all things showbiz, television and film. When at Media Wales headquarters she provides copy for WalesOnline, Western Mail, South Wales Echo and Wales on Sunday. When not at work she enjoys cycling, cooking (and eating), and is a film and music nerd.
Liz is the defence reporter for Wales Online. She has reported from Afghanistan and also covers general news and previously health.
Suzanne covers Merthyr Tydil Crown Court for Media Wales
Megan is a senior reporter for Wales Online. She joined the company in 2017 after working in factual and crime television production. She is an Essex native with a passion for baking.
Kate Rees is our What's On Content Writer. She covers events, activities and all things entertainment for WalesOnline.
Louise Evans is managing partner and head of tax at Grant Thornton's Cardiff office
Josh is Newport Audience Editor and Social Media Writer at WalesOnline. He has a background in features and interests include social media, Newport, food and drink, history, and TV and film.
Liz Keen covers Cardiff Crown Court for Media Wales

David is the Political Editor of Media Wales. He is based in Westminster and was previously the first Senedd Correspondent. David has been with Media Wales since 2002 and spent two years as a Business Correspondent. He regularly reports on faith issues.
Anthony is covering Rhondda Cynon Taf and the Merthyr as part of the BBC's Local Democracy Reporter project, which is aimed at enhancing reporting from local authorities across the UK
Katie is a video journalist and joined WalesOnline in 2017. Apart from writing, filming and editing, Katie enjoys watching reality TV and eating good food
Jonathan is a reporter in Media Wales' Merthyr Tydfil office, covering Merthyr Tydfil and Blaenau Gwent

Siân is a trainee WalesOnline reporter based in Newport.She recently graduated from Cardiff University with a Masters in International Journalism and interests include Newport, TV and film, history and music.

Shane Williams is Wales' leading Test try scorer of all time, scoring 58 tries during an 11-year international career that saw him capped 87 times for Wales. He also made four appearances for the British and Irish Lions across three separate tours. Originally from Glanamman in Carmarthenshire, he started his career at Neath, but is most associated with his Ospreys, where he played from 2003 to 2012. Since retiring, he has worked as a commentator and pundit, and has completed a number of triathlons, including Ironman Wales.

Rob is a reporter covering the Carmarthen area. He focuses on web and print content for the six regions that the Carmarthen Journal covers, and is the chief reporter for the Lampeter and Teifi editions.

Dr Cherrie Short CBE is associate dean of Global & Community Initiatives, and professor of practice at USC Suzanne Dworak-Peck School of Social Work in Los Angeles, California, and a visiting scholar at Cardiff University. Before taking on her role in research and academia, Dr Short served in Tony Blair’s administration for more than 10 years as an elected politician and as a UK Race Equality and Human Rights Commissioner. She also served as the Race Equality Commissioner for Wales, in which she oversaw all race relations in Wales, including the Race Relation Laws for the National Assembly of Wales. She is an experienced advocate for social justice, and a qualified forensic social worker, focusing on global approaches to social injustices, whose work has contributed to major social policy changes in local and central governments.
Karen is What's On and Lifestyle Editor of Media Wales and among the content she oversees is eating out, travel, music, theatre and film.
Matt is covering Cardiff and the Vale of Glamorgan as part of the BBC's Local Democracy Reporter project, which is aimed at enhancing reporting from local authorities across the UK

Nigel Owens is an international rugby referee. Born in 1971 in Mynyddcerrig near Cross Hands, he started refereeing in 1987, and eventually became one of the Welsh Rugby Union's first three professional referees in 2001. He refereed his first full international in 2003, and in 2015, he took charge of the World Cup Final, having become regarded as the world's best referee. He received an MBE for services to sport in 2016. Nigel came out as gay in 2007, and has also spoken openly about his battle with bulimia.

Ebbw Vale-born Hannah is a Media Wales veteran and award-winning journalist. She was big boss of all our What's On content, edited a number of our Celtic weekly titles, was news editor on the South Wales Echo, Magazines Editor, Arts Editor of the Western Mail and Agenda & Features Editor. Phew! She now works at a Group level as Head of Commercial Editorial for all our titles. A published author, her Western Mail columns were turned into the book, Diary of a Diet: A Little Book of Big. She also fronted a BBC One documentary on size issues called Fix My Fat Head. And if you like podcasts she presents one called Heavy which you find on iTunes.

Born in Swansea, Benjamin started out as reporter on the South Wales Evening Post, cutting his teeth as a patch reporter for Gorseinon. He worked as the Press Association's Wales Correspondent for five years before switching to BBC Wales - working for online, TV and radio.
John is a trainee reporter based in Swansea. He started at Wales Online in June 2019 after completing a News Journalism MA course at Cardiff University.
Rin is a lifestyle journalist specialising in green living, home interiors, wellbeing and crafts, and is author of The Indie Shopper blog.
Delme is assistant head of sport at Media Wales, specialising in rugby
Chris is a commercial writer and formerly worked as a news reporter and features writer.

Mike Phillips is one of Wales' greatest-ever scrum halves. The powerful former No 9 won 94 Welsh caps over 12 years international career, and played five Tests for the Lions over the course of two tours. Along the way he won two Grand Slams, three Six Nations titles and featured in the 2011 World Cup semi-final. Phillips retired from Wales duty in 2015. He has now joined WalesOnline's Rugby World Cup team as a columnist for the tournament in Japan.

Aled is a news editor and columnist. Having started at the Merthyr Express in 2001, he moved to the Western Mail in 2003. He writes a weekly column for the Western Mail and WalesOnline on a Friday. He is a big Cardiff City fan and also enjoys cricket, golf and running.

Paul Turner is Digital Development Editor for Wales Online, based in Swansea. He has been heavily involved with digital pretty much since it first arrived, responsible for the Evening Post website almost since its inception. Outside work, Paul is a keen gamer, walker and unpublished author of four books and counting...

Claire is a data journalist. She primarily covers stories based on government statistics, open data and Freedom of Information requests, as well as maintaining the Datastore section of WalesOnline. She has worked for Media Wales since 2010.
Robert Dalling is a senior reporter who joined WalesOnline in 2011 after completing his journalism training at Highbury College in Portsmouth.

Andrew Gwilym is our Swansea City Football Writer, covering the Premier League club home and away. He joined the company in November 2016 having previously held sports reporting roles with the Press Association and Westgate Sports Agency.
Adam Price is Plaid Cymru's Shadow Minister for Business Economy and Finance. He is the Assembly Member for Carmarthen East and Dinefwr and was formerly the MP for the same constituency.

Aamir is a reporter covering general news, features and everything else. He joined in July 2018 after graduating from Cardiff University with an MA in News Journalism. When not writing, you'll catch him playing or watching football.

Having served as MP for Cardiff West from 1987, Rhodri Morgan became AM for the same constituency in 1999. He became leader of Welsh Labour and First Minister in 2000, and held the position until 2009. He wrote a column for the Western Mail during his retirement and died in 2017.
Will is WalesOnline's political editor as maternity cover till 2021. He writes about history, politics and the environment. He supports West Bromwich Albion.
Eryl Jones is a designer and columnist at Media Wales
Dave covers Rhondda, Pontypridd and the Cynon Valley for Media Wales
David James is Head of News. In his time at Media Wales he has covered a range of fields including crime and politics.
James is a general reporter at Media Wales
Alison Sanders is WalesOnline's digital development editor. Alison started at WalesOnline in 2012 as a senior reporter and has previously covered local government.

David is one of the Multi Media Assistants. David also likes writing concert/music/TV show reviews. His favourite quote is \"In and of itself, nothing really matters. What matters is that nothing is ever in and of itself.\
Former Wales captain Gwyn Jones is a well-respected pundit for S4C and regular rugby columnist for WalesOnline and the Western Mail

Jessica is an online journalist at Media Wales. She looks after Wales Online’s social media channels and the website’s hyperlocal In Your Area sections. Away from the office she can be found reading, running and trying to be a better cook.
Jon Doel is Media Wales' multimedia sports reporter covering a host of Welsh sports for WalesOnline, the Western Mail, Wales on Sunday and South Wales Echo
Jeff runs Metier Consulting and is a former leader of Bridgend Council.

Huw Silk is a senior multimedia reporter for Wales Online. Originally from Cwmdu in the heart of the Black Mountains, he previously worked at the Northamptonshire Telegraph before moving back to Wales. He is a big sports fan.

Liz joined Media Wales as a trainee in January 2013, after studying at Cardiff School of Journalism. She now works as a specialist court correspondent. When she's not at work, Liz enjoys climbing, mountain biking and trapeze.

WalesOnline's Chief Football Writer, covering the fortunes of all our clubs - including the national side - with the biggest breaking stories, in-depth interviews and on-the-pitch analysis across the game in Wales
Nathan Bevan writes features on music, art, stage and screen, as well as several columns.
Matthew Southcombe is rugby audience editor at WalesOnline. Matt started here in March 2014, specialising in rugby, football and golf.
I am a senior reporter covering news, feature and a bit of everything else. I love the theatre, books and good food.

Gemma is the Neath Port Talbot reporter for WalesOnline. She also writes for and oversees the weekly Neath Port Talbot Courier and our Neath Port Talbot Online social media. She joined the company in 2015 after studying at Cardiff and Swansea Universities.
Education correspondent and part-time columnist. Big Roxy Music fan
Millie Thwaites is a reporter from MailOnline Australia, currently spending three months at WalesOnline
Darren covers news and features for the Western Mail, Wales on Sunday and the South Wales Echo.
Glen is the Cardiff City correspondent for Wales Online and abreast of all things Bluebirds.

Cardiff City season ticket holder Scott Johnson is our Cardiff City fan columnist. Scott is a regular contributor on the View From the Ninian website and has written two books on the club, Cardiff City: Rebranded and The Blues Are Up, covering their 2013 promotion.
Gareth Griffiths. Sports correspondent with Media Wales covering rugby, cricket and a variety of other sports. Covered Welsh success at London 2012 last year
Carly joined in 2017 after journalism stints in Gloucestershire and Plymouth.

Marcus Hughes is a senior reporter from Newport. He started at Wales Online in 2017 after completing the News Journalism MA course at Cardiff University. Marcus primarily covers the Newport and Cardiff patch.
Lorna Doran is Content Direct Editor for WalesOnline and a trained video journalist. She has a background in print journalism and has worked as an assistant editor, design sub-editor and writer.
Award winning photographer/videographer and picture editor at Media Wales

David is Senedd Correspondent for WalesOnline. He started his career in Newport at the South Wales Argus in 2007. David moved to WalesOnline in 2014. He lives in Cardiff, despite being Bristolian. He likes the Glaswegian band Mogwai, weird documentaries, international news and tea shops.
Clare is the crime correspondent, and is responsible for www.walesonline.co.uk/crime.
Sue heads the commercial production team who design ad features, in-paper supplements, WM-branded magazines, Media Wales magazines and commercial products.
